div.head: LORD ROBERTS ON THE ARMY.
div.p: What “Bobs” has to say about the Army is what the Army and the nation want to hear. And Lord Roberts says his say to the extent of five-and-twenty pages in the current number of the Nineteenth Century. His article is large­ly historical, since his object is to draw a com­parison between the Army "as it was and as it is." All that he has to say on this side of the question is deeply interesting. In his own person he has seen the new grafted on the old. He has commanded the old Army in the field and led it to victory. He has also at an ad- vanoed age and bowed by personal trouble with astonishing vigor commanded and led to victory the largest army that we have ever put into the field, fighting under conditions as far removed from those under which Lord Roberts first saw service as is the khaki uniform from the bright coatees and cumbrous stocks in which the Peninsular campaigns were fought Lord Roberts's claims to reverence, respect and admiration rest on a sure basis of experience and devotion to the highest sense of duty.

It is on his advice that interest will be fixed. The historical comparison is extremely interesting, and it leads to the reasoned optimism of a great soldier. In 1854 the British Army, at home and abroad, totalled 189,980 men, with 120 field guns. There was no Reserve and no Volunteer Force. With die Militia and Yeomanry, we had at the most 200,000 men. These men were incessantly drilled, but badly trained ; com­missions were purchased by officers whose education and intelligence were in inverse ratio to their gallantry.; the whole force was armed with inferior weapons and the men were not taught to shoot. In its day that little British Army went far and did wonders. But those were the days of point-blank range and close forma­tion. Since then by degrees we have adapt­ed our forces and our weapons to the changed conditions brought about by the scientific improvement of arms and ammunition and we have always managed to “muddle through.’’ It is not hard to understand that Lord Roberts, who knew the old Army, and who has known the new, in barracks, on pa­rade, and in action, should be something of an optimist, or that, seeing very clearly how much still remains to be done and the way in which progress should be attempted, he should give his advice with an apparent belief that advice may be followed before it is too late.

But the root of the matter lies rather in the spirit than the letter, It is the spirit alone that can revivify, and to all appearances our War Office is still imbued with the spirit that has done its best to kill the Army and the Empire. There has been a deal of fiddling with Army Corps and Districts and territorial designations and buttons and overcoats and the minutiae of drill. But the Army is as in­sufficient and inefficient as it was before the South African War showed us terrible things. If we desired an illustration of the permanence of bad tradition (fortunately good tradition, courage and tenacity, and self-confidence, is equally permanent in the British Army), we could hot have a better one than Lord Ro­berts' story of how after adopting the Armstrong gun, our first breechloader, in 1858, we re­turned six years later to muzzle-loaders for our artillery. This brilliant notion can only have emanated from the same source as the amazing apathy which left the British Army in 1904 without the essential supply of quickfiring field- guns which had been tested, approved, and promised a year previously. Obviously we must slay this demon of incompetence in organisation before we can turn with much hope of their application to the reforms suggested by Lord Roberts

It is not, however, too much to hope that even our troglodyte authorities will pay the compliment of attention to these suggestions. Lord Roberts urges the importance of the Cavalry arm. We must add largely to the numbers of our cavalry and the officers must be much more highly trained. To effect this, without undue interference with the polo and hunting which are “in moderation’’ so valuable a training for a cavalry officer, they must be better paid. If we want the -best we must pay for the best and make the service attractive to those whose abilities are good enough to ensure success in other pro­fessions. We must also have a very large body of Mounted infantry, not lesfthan ooc- fourth of the Infantry establishment. Than sinoe in modern warfare the ooutrol and guidance in aotion must pass to oompany commanders and aeotion leaden it is "es­sential that their intelligence, self-reliance, and power of leading should be on a proportionately higher level." Volleys being things of the past and so much depend­ing on accuracy of sum and fire discipline, “special attention should be paid to individual care and ooutrol of ammunition." The neces­sity for higher training aud for the servioee of men as officers and non-commissioued officers, whose intelligence and keeaness is beyond question, is further emphasised by Lord Ro­ berts’s oonviction that in the future most operations, indudiug the final attack, most,be carried out uuder cover of darkness, a lesson that is further enforced by the experiences of the Russo-Japanese campaign. “A terrible lesson,” says Lord Roberts with grim warning, “awaits the nation whose soldiers find them­selves opposed to equally brave but better trained opponents on tbe field of battle."

We have only to look to the blood-stained plains of Manchuria to take the lesson to heart. With the great commander's views on the neoeeeity of some lorm of national servioe we are in sympathy. Lord Roberts holds no brief for oonacnption. He prefers the voluntary soldier, but he feels, that all classes “must be prepared to undergo suoh a modicum of train­ing as will make themjntelul as soldiere” in time of need. Surely uis object and tbe physical regeneration of the nation oould be achieved by the enoouragement end ex ten sion of the association whioh interests itself ic fostering the military training ot our youth between the ages of twelve and sixteen, or thereabouts. It wonld be the nation’* surest defence against the terrors of con soription. If Lord Roberta can indace thi authorities to see to this aud to making the service attractive and possible for tb right stamp of man, be may render to tb Army, which he no longer commands, servioe almost as great as those services in the field which have earned him his sure place in th ranks of the world’s great soldiers.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR THE MIKADO’S THANKS. STOESSEL PRAISES THE JAPS
div.p: Tokio, January 7.
The Emperor in a rescript thanks General Nogi, the Third Army and Admiral Togo and his fleet for the capture of Port Arthur. (R.)
Port Arthur, January 7.

In the course of a conference between Generals Nogi and Stoessel, the latter praised accuracy of the Japanese artillery. He also offered to General Nogi his charger, which Nogi accepted on behalf of the army saying they would always treat it with the greatest kindness out of respect for the brave General.
(Reuter.)
Port Arthur, January 8.
The transfer of the prisoners here is completed. Fifty per cent of the Russian officers have given their parole. The remainder, including Generals Fock and Smyrnoff, prefer to be imprisoned in Japan.
(Reuter.)

div.head: JERUSALEM. SANGUINARY RELIGIOUS DISPUTE
div.p: Jerusalem, January 8.

A sanguinary dispute occurred here between the Latin and Greek clergy whilst the latter were performing the Christmas midnight mass. The Patriarch was officiating at Bethlehem. The Latins were apparently the aggressors, for when the Greek ecclesiastics in vestments were issuing from the northern entrance of the Giotto of the Nativity, the Franciscan monks barred their way and a collision ensued, with the result that one Franciscan was seriously wounded and the Patriarch’s janissary slightly so. The Governor of Jerusalem went to the Grotto. Notwithstanding their exclusive ownership of the eastern entrance, the Greeks were ultimately allowed to pass through the northern door, hence the jealousy. (Reuter.)

div.head: TRADE OF UNITED KINGDOM.
div.p: London, January 7.
The imports during the year ending the 31st December have increased by £8,761,835 and the exports by £10,017,789. (Reuter.)

div.head: CONDITION OF RUSSIA.
BRUTAL EXCESSES OF POLICE.
div.p: Moscow, January 7. Owing to the brutality used in suppressing the recent demonstration hero, the Municipality has suspended payment of the gendarmery until the responsible persons are punished. (Reuter.)

St. Petersburg, January 7. The Editors of a large number of Russian newspapers have forwarded to the organs of the revolutionary movement published on the Continent a signed account of the brutal excesses of the St Petersburg police in supressing the student demonstrations. The signatories declare that these events are calculated to completely destroy the illusion as regards the possibility of obtaining, under the existing regime, the most elementary guarantees for personal safety. (Reuter.)
St. Petersburg, January 8. A monster banquet is being arranged here in order to protest against the bureaucracy. (Reuter.)
THE TSAR’S AUTHORITY. HOLY SYNOD’S PROTEST.

St. petersburg, January 7. M. Pobienoszeff, Procurator of the Holy Synod, has sent an address to the Tsar protesting against the insensate machinations of certain nobles to induce His Majesty to weaken his authority. He says that the Tsar possesses every right, except the right to break his oath, to preserve intact the autocracy and the Orthodox Faith. (Reuter.)

div.head: TROUBLE IN MOROCCO. ENCOUNTER WITH THE PRETENDER.
div.p: Tangier, January 7.

A fight has taken place 30 kilometres from Ujda between the troops of the Pretender and the Moorish forces. The Pretender was beaten but retired to a selected spot where reinforcements awaited him. The Imperial troops whilst pursuing the enemy, fell into ambuscade where they were completely routed, losing 400 killed and wounded. (Reuter.)

div.head: M. SYVETON’S SUCCESSOR. ADMIRAL BIENAIME ELECTED.
div.p: Paris, January 8.
Admiral Bienaimé has been elected deputy in place of M. Syveton. (Reuter.)

div.head: EGYPTIANS IN PARIS. PETE ACCESSION DAY.
div.p: Paris, January The Egyptians living in Paris and the friends of Egypt assembled under the presidency of Zaki Bey to fête the Khedive’s accession day. They sent their good wishes to the Khedive. (Havas.)

div.head: ACTION AGAINST THE BOURSE
div.p: Before the Commercial Chamber of the Mixed Tribunals of Alexandria, the case of Bustros v. Société da la Bourse d’Alexandrie and all the members of the Association des Courtiers de Commerce, came on for hearing. This case is of great interest to the community as it involves the locus standi of the Association, and may have important consequences. We will report it fully. The petitioners are represented by Maitres Le Moine and Carton de Wiart, the Société de la Bourse by Maitres Lebsohn and Palagi, the 74 members of the Association by Maitres X. Socolis and Colucci. The pleadings will probably not terminate before this evening.

div.head: THE BOULANGERIE MECANIQUE.
div.p: Owing to the length of this case, another interesting suit has been postponed to the 20th February. It is the action brought by the liquidation of the Boulangerie Mécqnique against Mr. Valere Mabille, the Franco-Belgian financier, as well known by his extraordinary likeness to King Leopold of Belgium as by his business capacities, and also against Mr. P. Remy, the Belgian Consul in Alexandria, Me. Manusardi is for the liquidators, Me. Carton de Wiart for Mr. Valero Mabille, Me. Colucci for Count Remy.
CAIRO GRANDO HAMMAM

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: THE S.Y. “Argonaut” arrived at Alexandria yesterday.
Bubonio Plague. — Two fresh cases and a, death have occurred in Toukh district and one case at Suez, since Saturday.
The Reunion des Familles Society gave a most successful dance at Monferrato’s Hall on Saturday evening, which was attended by a large gathering of members.

New Doctors—The Ministry of the Interior, on the proposition of the Sanitary Administration, has authorised Drs. Oscar Stross, Garabet Arakel and Constantin Schopoulos to practice as physicians in Egypt

The North German Lloyd’s S.S. “Schles-wig” is due at Alexandria this evening with about 160 cabin passengers. The S.S. "Hohen-zolleru" is. making her maiden voyage on this route and is due here on Monday next This is the commencement of the weekly service of this compauy between Alexandria and Europe.

Coal Imports.—The imports of coal into Alexandria from the 1st January to the 31st ulto. amounted to 1,057,441 tons, as compared with 1,007,970 tons during the year 1903. Of this total, Newcastle sent 240,694 tons, the Welsh coaling districts 601,755 tons, the Scotch districts 108,310 tons, and Yorkshire 58,875 tons, while the Imports of other qualities came to 48,307.

H.M. Transport “Soudan” (Capt S. de B. Lockyer, R.N.R.) arrived at Port Said at noon on Saturday from Bombay. She had on board the 1st Battalion Royal Fusiliers and details, making a total of 1,336 of all ranks. The Royal Fusiliers, numbering 440, are to be stationed on arrival in England at Parkhurst Barracks, Isle of Wight The officer commanding is Major and Brevet-Colonel C. V. F. Townshend, C.B., D.S.O. The “Soudan” left for Southampton at midnight.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Marquis di Rudini, a former Prime Minister for many years of Italy, arrived at Alexandria by the Italian boat and is staying at the Savoy,Cairo. The Marquis looks exceep-ingly well and will go up as far as Khartoum. On his return he will stay for a long time in Cairo. The Marquis Salvago-Raggi met the statesman at the station and accompanied him to the Savoy, where an apartment had been reserved for him. The Marquis will afterwards proceed to Ery-threa in order to decide what measures should be taken fur the development oi Italy's Red Sea colony. H. H. the Khedive received the newly-appointed judges in audience to-day at Abdeen Palace. Lt-Col. Sir Curzon Wyllie and Lady Wyllie have arrived at Helouan and are staying at the Grand Hotel Lady Mariot, Mr. and Mrs. G. H. Blunt, and Capt Blunt are also residing at the Grand Hotel Helouan. Col. and Mrs. Huddleston and Miss Etches have lately arrived at the Grand Hotel Helouan, where they intend to stay for some weeks. We are authorised to state that there is absolutely no truth in the report that Chitty Bey is to be transferred from Alexandria to Cairo. Canon Holland, of Canterbury, preached in the morning and evening yesterday at All Saints’ Church, Cairo.

F. W. BLUM. Mr. F. W. Blum, who has been working for about three years in Alexandria as Church of England missionary to the Jews, died last night at the Deaconesses’ Hospital, Alexandria. Mr. Blum had been unwell for some time and recently underwent a successful operation; but unfortunately an attack of dysentery intervened and he succumbed after a few days’ illness. He leaves a wile who is very delicate and two young children. Mrs. Blum is in Liepsic with the children. Mr. Blum, who was a German Jew (Ashkenazi), was born in Jerusalem in 1855 and was baptized by Pastor Faltin of Kishineff. Since 1902 be had worked in Alexandria as the missionary of the London Society for Promoting Christianity amongst the Jews. . The funeral will leave the Hospital at 11 a.m. to-morrow.

For Arabs. Distance 1 mile 1 furlong. Entrance P.T. 50. Entries close Wednesday, 11st inst, at 8 p.m.

div.head: FREE STATE LANDS. AUTHORISED- STATEMENT.
div.p: From time to time rumours are current that negotiations are in progress for the sale by Government of all the free State lands. Doubtless there are many financiers who would very gladly take up such a scheme, and proposal with this object have been made. We are authorized to state, however, on the best authority, that the Government has no intention of handing over en bloc these lands to any syndicate or group. There are many applications for waste lands in the hands of the Government, and an official intimation was issued some time ago that these would not bo considered before April. The Ministries of Finance and Public Works are studying the whole question, and meantime rumours of large concessions may be treated as mere canards.

div.head: ARRIVAL OF PERSIAN AMBASSADOR.
div.p: H. H. Prince Aria el-Daula, Persian Ambassador at Constantinople, arrived at Alexandria this morning by the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Habsburg. His Highness was received on his arrival by H. E. Mirza Ali Askar Khan, Persian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General in Egypt, Mihran Khan Kalfaian, Persian Consul at Alexandria, Mohamed Bey Assem, Sub-Governor of Alexandria, and representatives of the local authorities, besides a number of local notabilities. A guard of honor was furnished by a detachment of Customs Guards, and on disembarking his Highness was escorted by a detachment of mounted police to the residence of the Persian Consul, where he partook of breakfast Afterwards the Prince proceeded to the Carlton Hotel, Bulkelev, where, as on his previous visit, he will remain during his stay here. The Persian Consulate at Alexandria denies the report that Prince Arfa el Dawla has been entrusted with a special mission to the Khedive on behalf of the Shah. His Highness has just returned on the completion of his mission the Tsar.

div.head: THE VOYAGE OF THE “MONGOLIA".
div.p: The P. 0. SB. “Mongolia" reached Port Said on Thursday afternoon, and after taking in 1,200 mail bags and 800 tons of ooal, left for Suez, from which port she sailed on Friday evening. The voyage from England was full of disagreeable incidents. She was detained for two days at Tilbury in the blackest of fogs, which rendered it impossible for the passengers to go ashore, but when the fog lifted for a few hours on Christmas Day she lost no time in starting. The overland passengers reached Marseilles on Friday, December 30, to be told that the “Mongolia” had only just left Gibraltar, and they must stay at a hotel at the company's expense. When the steamer arrived on the following day, so strong a mistral was blowing from the N. N. W. that she could neither get into dock, nor could a tug proceed to her. She therefore took up a position of safety under the hills to the west of the town, where she was shortly joined by a dozen other steamers which were unable to make the port. On New Year’s Day the French agent of the P. and 0. Company made some in adequate arrangements by which some 200 passengers succeeded in boarding the steamer with their luggage. The sea was then less rough because the wind had dropped somewhat bat it was so cold that no one was surprised to see snow falling. The bad weather and numerous snow storms lasted until the Straits of Messina had been passed, after which the weather became fairly good, with the exception of occasional showers of hail and rain. The ship travelled well in spite of the rough sea, and averaged from 16 .to 17 miles an hour every day. Nearly 100 passengers were booked for Cairo, including Sir Curzon and Lady Wyllie, Captain the Hon. G. and Mrs. Baring, Mr. Forestier Walker and Dr. Sand with. Among those proceeding to the Far East was Major-General “Keggy" Slade, welll known to many old Egyptians as a staff officer in the campaigns in this country from 1882 to 1885. He is now Inspector General of Artillery, and has received orders to/obtain permission from the Japanese

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE. “ SIBERIA.”
div.p: Owing to pressure on our space, we are oompelled to hold over our report of the production of Siberia until tomorrow.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.
div.p: Those in want of a hearty laugh could not do better than pay a visit to the Abbas Helmy Theatre, where mirth is combined with first-rate music. The Soarez operetta company is meeting with a success, which was richly deserved. Full houses are the order of the day, rather night, and the auditorium generally resounds with laughter from beginning to end of the performance. Les P'tetites Brebis on Saturday and La Mascotte last night were huge successes. This may he readily understood when we say that the present company is the best comic opera combination that has ever visited Egypt The singers are faultless, the music is equally excellent, and the costumes and staging are admirable. Signa. Soarez and Sig. Gravina are alone worth going to the theatre to hear. Capitan Teresa tonight should fill the house again. Mr. Monferrato has distinctly scored this time.

We are happy to state that the overtures which the Board of the Ramleh Railway has made with a view to meeting the wishes of their clients were adopted by: the Ramlehites at the mass meeting on Saturday evening, and that harmonious relations have at last'been re-established between the. railway directors, and the public. The mass meeting on Saturday evening was, a great success. In spite of the inclemency of the weather and of the ravages of influenza there was a large and enthusiastic gathering of Ramlehites, and the venerable pile, known to fame as the Theatre of Bacos, was crowded from top to bottom with an audience who bad mustered from every quarter of the Ramleh district. Soon after 9 o'clock the president of the Ramleh delegates, Mr. Benjamin Arbib, mounted the rostrum amidst the acclamations of the assembled Ramlehites, and with a weighty and dignified eloquence pronounced the following oration in Italian:---

div.head: THE CHAIRMAN’S SPEECH.
div.p: Signori ! Vi preghiamo, prima di tutto, di ascoltarci con calma' e di non interrompere gli oratort finché non avranno finite di parlare; d’altronde quetto cheio diro in Italiano sara ripetuto in - reso un conto esatto di quanto i0 vi sotto-mettero e la parola sari accordata a tutti quelli che la domanderanno. Dall’ultima seduta a questa, abbiamo fatto il nostro possibile per calmare gli spiriti, fecendo passi al governatorato ed all'amministrazione della compagnia per cio che riguarda i disordini causati della presenza della polizia alla stazione, e siamo riusciti a allontanare la forza anche per il bene dei poveri agenti che morivano di fame. D’altronde la delegazione ha sempre pensato che le differenze che sorgono tra il pubblieo ed una pubblica amministrazione devono essere solo risolti civilmente e non all’ombra della polizia, che e spauracchio per i malfattori e non per gente onesta quale noi siamo. Signori ! noi siamo riusciti a fare mantenere dalla compagnia i prezzi di abbonamento di prima, solo quest’ultima ha domandato delle limitazione. L’amministrazione fara degli abbonamenti trimestrali, - semistrali ed annuali e cio nel modo seguente: Per un trimestre dara tre carnets che saranno valevoli per i tre mesi e alia scadenzadi questi i biglietti rimaneuti non avranno piu alcun valore. Ogni carnet avra 120 biglietti, cioe 4 ogni giorno. Per un semestre dara 6 carnett } nella stessa proporzione del trimestre. Per un anno dark 12 carnets nella proporzione come sopra. E bene inteso che questi carnett sono personali esclusivamente. Per mezzo della nostra energica abnegazione i carnets oggi essistenti resteranno allo stesso | prezzo di P.T.. 77 per ogni carnets di 50 , biglietti di prima classe e di P.T. 37 1/2 per , ogni carnet di 50 biglietti di terza classe. I : mezzi biglietti saranno calcolati nella medesima proporzione. Noi abbiamo insistito presso S.E. Bogos Pacha Nubar perche alla limitazione dei viaggi sia dato un compenso per i viaggi intermediari ed a tale uopo domandammo 10 biglietti ogni mese al di fuori di quelli compresi in ogni carnet Insistemmo pure fare aumentare di 4 bigliet-ti quei carnets che dovranno servire per i mesi di 81 giorni e cio per eliminare qualsiase lesione d’interesse a torto degli abbonati Per queste nostre domande e stato risposto al di la j delle nostre aspettative. S.E Baghos Nubar Pacha ha aqcordato 400 biglietti per ogni trimestre cio epiu di 138 biglietti ogni mese invece di 120 che essi ci accordavano. Per tale operato vi propongo di applaudire al consiglio di Amministrazione della Ramleh ed a S.E. Boghos Nubar Pacha. Come vedete in poche ore noi siamo riusciti ad ottenere una seluzione pratica, efficace ed accettabile per tutti. Noi speriamo che voi tutti siete contenti del nostro opera to onde se voi ci approvate alzate le mani. Primo di lasciare la parola agli altri oratori permettetemi di ringrasiare a nome di tutti i Ramlisti laCommissione dei locatari di Alessandria alla cui testa come Presidente onorario sta il filantropico Signor Alderson che sempre primo dove c'e da siutare chi ha di bisogno. I nostri ringraziamenti vadano pure al Presidente effetivo di questa Commissione Signor Cavaliere Ronci ed a tutti i suoi colleghi e specialmente al Signor Quintavalle ed al Signor Menasse. Permettetemi che a nome di voi tutti ringrazi la stampa che si e mostrata simpatica per i nostri reclami. ________ Ringrazio voi tutti abitanti di Ramleh che in questa occasione vi siete mostrati solidali, energici, nomini seri e non montoni quail ci crede-van’o Siamo sempre vigili difensori dei nostri .interessi, siamo sempre uniti e cosi saremo siamo sempre uniti e cosi saremo sempre forti .per la garanzia nostri diritti. Ringraziamo il Signor Coleyanni proprietario di questo theatro che ha facilitato le nostre riuniotti e ’ vi -preghiamo .di facilitare il suo commereio essendo suoi fedeli clienti. Perthettetemi in ultimo che a nome di voi tutti e mio, renda omaggio all’opara indifessa del nostro Comitato. La soluzione che io vi ho annunziato non intralcia in alcun medo i lavori del Comitato, obe seranno continuati per la garanzia e la salvagnardis dei nostri interessi, Io vi propongo un voto di fiducis e di plauso al nostro Comitato

div.head: THE OPPOSITION.
div.p: The president’s speech was followed by a dis-course from M. Zenie, another member of the Ramleh Delegation who spoke in French and Arabic. He dwelt on the great debt whioh all the Ramlehites were under to the president, owing to whose energy, pertinacity, and diplo macy the population of Ramleh had been freed from the yoke which the, directors of -the Railway Company had vainly endeavoured to place on them. While this speech was proceed-ing it became clear that there was a strong opposition to the amicable settlement as proposed by the president. But by the explanation which Mr. Quintavalle addressed to the dissen-tients, it was manifest that this opposition was due to failure to grasp the tenour of the president’s speech. One member of the audience reproached the meeting with the charge that all they really wanted was to travel free. This opprobrious imputation was severely resented by the Ramlehites. Another incident occurred when two engineers got up and addressed the meeting on the subject of a motor service. When these gentlemen began to speak, the delegatee withdrew, as the subject under dis-cussion was not on the order of the day moreover the president had- refused to assent to these gentlemen, Messrs. Arcondoulis and Movesse, making any 'remarks. The delegates and the Ramlehites then marched to the residences of Mr. Alderson and. M. Jacot de Combes, whom they serenaded. ' The delegates have been entrusted with a mandate to enter into negotiations with the company in order to settle the position of the population of Ibrahimieh.

div.head: THE BOARD'S STATEMENT.
div.p: We have received the following notice from the Alexandria and'Ramleh Railway Com-pany :--- “The Board of Directors, taking into consideration that the suppression of season tickets or “abonnements,” was not decided on with the object of increasing the tariff but only with the intention of putting an cud to abuses, which had taken such proportions as to be very prejudicial to the company’s interests, and being desirous of conciliating, as much as possible, these interests with those of the inhabitants of Ramleh, the Board has decided to replace the old season tickets by books of tickets, which will be offered for sale, on and after the 1st April next. " These books will be strictly personal, the owner’s photograph will be attached to them, and they will contain a number of tickets calculated on the basis of 400 journeys per quarter, or three months. "There will be separate books for three, six, and twelve months, containing 400; 800, or 1,600 tickets, at the prices of £3, £5 1/2 and £ 9 1/2 respectively, for the first class and £1.750, £3.250, and £5.700 for the second class. “These books oft tickets will be valid for three months, from the 1st January, 1st April, 1st July, and 1st October of each year. "The tickets contained in these books will only be valid when they are detached by the company's agents and used during the quarter, half-year, or year to which they refer. 'Provisionally, and up to the time of the employment of the above mentioned personal books of tickets, the former season-ticket holders, whose tickets have now expired, will be able to receive for the first quarter, in ordinary ticket books, a number of tickets calculated on the basis of 400 tickets per quarter, at the price of £3 per 400 first-class and £1.750 second-class tickets, from the day following the expiration of each season ticket, until the 31st March next. “Independently of the new books of personal tickets, the discount allowed from the first January last, on ordinary books of 50 tickets, will be maintained, their price remains fixed at P.T. 75 for 1st class and P.T. 35 1/2 for 2nd class. “By order of the Board of Directors. "(Signed): Jacot des combes."

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE.
div.p: Judge Kershaw and Judge Vanx have been appointed as Inspectors of the Committee of 8urveillance of the Ministry of Justice. Judge Keshaw will be specially entrusted with the inspection of the Native Parquets.

div.head: IRRIGATION DEPARTMENT.
div.p: The Minister of Public Works has sanctioned the following appointments :--- Mr. T. H. Clowes, Inspector of the 4th Circle, to be promoted Inspector-General of Irrigation in Upper Egypt in succession to Mr. A. L Webb, Under-Secretary of State for Irrigation. Mr. M. G. B. Ireland, Inspector of the Zifteh Circle, has been appointed Inspector of the 4th Circle. Mr. H. G. Finlaison, Director of the Delta Barrage, has been appointed Inspector of the Zifteh Circle. Mr. Webb has been appointed President of the Special Council of Discipline at the P.WD. in succession to Sir W. Garstin.

div.head: SAVOY SMALL DANCE.
div.p: There was a most successful dance at the Savoy on Saturday evening, the usual habitués of the Savoy, as well as most of the officers of | the Egyptian Army and the Army of Occupa-tion, being present. Among others we noticed : Col. J. K. Watson, Coles Pasha and the Misses Coles, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Royle, Baron von Oppenheim, Lady Clark, etc. The restaurant was full up as usual on Saturday evenings,both for dinner and supper. Mr. Charles Royle had a party of 5 and Mr., Mrs, and Miss Bell a party of 8, including Mr, Higgins, Mr. James, Mr, and Mrs., Crawley

and Miss Stevenson, Mr and Mme. Meimarachi entertained Baron and Baronne Aliotti and Mr. Spartali, Mrs. Lovell Rodgers had a party of 4, Mrs. K. Simon and the Miss Simon had 5 guests to dinner, Dr. Armstrong entertained 6 triends to dinner, Mr. and Mrs. Peckham had a party of 4, etc.
At the table of Lady Clark and Mrs. Jay, we remarked Baron von Oppenheim and Baron von Haeften.
The restaurant was again quite full for supper.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourdhui a midi et demie)
div.p: La hausse s’accentue sur la plupart des valours. Pour quelques-unes le terrain gagne est considerable : ainsi la Banque d’Athenes remonte de 118 1/2 a 123 acheteurs, la Filature do 13/16 k 15/16, la Delta Light de 14 3/8 a 14 9/16.

La Banque Nationals attaint egalement 24 9/16, l’Agrioole 10 1/16, la Midra 50, la Delta Land 3 15/16, la Daira Sanieh 22, la Brasserie des Pyramides 133, les Markets 23/6, la Salt and Soda 43/6, l’Anglo-Amerioau Nile 4 15/16, la Ramleh Railway 8 3/16, etc.
Par contre la Crown Browery flechit a 220 et la Khedivial Mail a 3 7/8.
Le marche a ete anim5 et le nombre des transactions considerable sur la plupart des valeurs.

div.head: CREDIT FONCIER EGYPTIEN
div.p: Messieurs les Actionnaires sont convoqués à l’Assemblée Générale Ordinaire qni aura lien le mardi 31 Janvier 1906 à 8 heures de l’aprèt-midi, au Siège Social au Caire.
Ordre du Jour :

1° Lecture du Rapport du Conseil d’Administration sur les Affaires sociales ; 2° Lecture du Rapport des Censeurs ; 8° Approbation des Comptes et fixation du dividende pour l’exereioe 1904 ; 4° Nomination d’Administrateurs ; 6° Nomination de deux Censeurs pour l'exercice 1906. Tout porteur de 50 actions a le droit d'asuster à l'Assemblée Générale et conformément à l'article 28 des Statuts les Aotions devront être déposées : En Egypte au pim tard le 30 Janvier 1905. En Europe au plus tard le 15 Janvier 1905. Les dépôts seront reçus : Au Oaire, au Siège 8ooial ; A Alexandrie, au Crédit Lyonnais ;
En Europe, à la Banque de Paris et des Pays-B te, — au Crédit Lyonnais, à la Société Générale — au Comptoir National d'Esoompte — à la Société Générale de Crédit Industriel et Commercial.

div.head: Municipality d’Alexandrie
AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture du bereim nécessaire aux divers animaux de ses services. Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 30. Lo cahier des oharges est déposé au Bureau du Nettoiement où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés. Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 17 oourant à midi. Elles pourront également être déposées en séanoo de la Délégation le même jour à 5h. p.m. L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la meu- jn i “Soumission pour fourniture du bereim nécessaire aux animaux de 1a Municipalité.” Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du oahier des charges, devra être remis au service de la Comptabilité avant l’ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 17 courant A midi. L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. Ciutaway. Alexandrie, le 5 janvier 1905. 25,198-3-8

div.head: BOURSE KHEDIVIALE
div.p: Remrquec sur le marche du disponible et oontrats. . Samedi, le 7 janvier 1905. Ooton.—La semaine a eu on manvais debut pour le disponible, mais depuis deux joun la demande a ili meilleure, quoique, au fond, elle soit limiWo et ne porte quo sur lesqualitds superieures. Quant aux prix, lea fluctuations ont ltd insignifiantee et en definitive, nous revenons aux ooura de la semaine passe®, taut pour le Mit-Afifi que poar les provenances Hante-Egypte et Fayoum. Pour ce qui est des Abassi etdes Joannovioh la oote a subi uue reduction de 1/4-h 1/2 talari. En franoogaro, il n’y a absolument aueune operation A signaler. En oontrats.—Le marche a ete affsote un pen par la ohfite d'un de nos grands faiseore, lis grAoe A la suspensioi^faffaires de remsdi et de lundi dernier A l’oooasion du nonvel an, la premiire impression a eu le tempi de s'effaoer et par la suite la tenue du marche a ete asses bonne, malgrt le ton de fiublemseet l’hesitation qui n’ont ces»e de regner. Quoi qu’il en soit, le prompt arrangement intervena entre le debitear et ses oreanoiere pour uue liquidation amiable a enleve un grand sonoi Ala place et aujourd’hui on pent dire que let apprihen-lion* out diiparu, d’autAutplus quol« liqaidv tions des oontrats ont ili toutes regali ferement pAyM.' l Lee transactions A la ojrbjUle nisou pas enormes, mais le oourant est meiQeur. Pouroequi est des prix la oote s’inscrit en baisee de 8/16 sur la semaine dernfore. La filature semble toujoure rdservee pour les livraisons eloignees. La nouvelle reoolte est soutenu etdonno lieu A un peu plus d'affaires, mais, en somme, il u'y a rien d'important, mlgre l’aooentuation dans le rapproohemeut des oours dee deux reooltgs^ .(xt ainet de coton,—Le oalme et la faiblesae persistent malgre lee gros embarquemeots et lea besoins du moment das exporteteurs et la oote du disponible s’en est ressentie, les oours ayant fini .A P.T. 1 20/40 au-desaous dp la semaine denutre. En franco-gare.—Aueune affaire. Les contests sont negliges et les transso-tions qui ont eu lieu de temps A autre restent sansaucunb importance. By a bien eu quelques fluctuations et la olOture est eu reprise sur le point le plus bas, mais, qoand rndme, la tendance est pour la foiblesse eto’est F.T. 1 25/40 que, en resume, nous avons perdu sur la semaine passee. riveit.—Nullite d'affaires sur toute la ligue, taut pour la disponible que pour les oontrats, et lee oours restent tout-A-fait nominaux.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.
CHRISTMAS FESTIVITIES.
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
Suakin, December 30.

H.M.S. “Sealark,” survey ship, returned here from Sheikh Barghout on the 23rd inst. At daybreak on the 24th the Commander's valet was suddenly taken ill, and expired very shortly after. The funeral procession took place at 2.30 p.m. the same day. All the officers and crew followed the mortal remains of the deceased in boats to the Christian cemetery on Quarantine Island. The burial service was read by the Commander and the usual naval honors were paid to the deceased at the grave.

The same evening (Christmas Eve) a grand concert was given by the Suakin Cosmopolitan Orchestra, under the directorship of Mr. Henry Moss, the popular Assistant Commandant Suakin Police. The orchestra is composed of a number of Sudan Government employes and is international. The function was a thorough and well deserved success, and the performance reflected the greatest credit on Mr. Muss. The Town Hall, where the concert was held, was tastefully decorated with flags and banners, kindly lent for the occasion by H.M.S. “Sealark” and the Sudan Government steamer “Mukhbir.” The progamma opened by the orchestra playing the March '‘Sardinia.” The Arabic song “Bi Cita Real Yabba Gows Ni,” by El Sayid el Hassan, was heartily encored, especially by the Egyptians. Mr. Kirby and Sig. Ura were successful in their violin duet and were encored several times. Mrs. Purvis elicited great praise by her charming rendering of the pianotorte solo, “Preghiera del Mose.” The orchestra played once more,this time "The English Gentleman," and was encored a second time. Corporal George, K.E., gave a most amusing recitation entitled “British Pluck,” by Kipling. Mr. Razzle, in his banjo solo, was a great success. Commander Somerville, R.N., of H.M.S. “Sealark,” at the request of the guests, sang an Irish comic song, and was encored so heartily that he had to give another. A. B. Myers, R.N., of H.M.S. "Sealark,” sang very well, and was encored by his mates to such an extent that he, too, had to give another song. The Khedivial Anthem was then played by the orchestra, and the proceedings ended with “God Save the King.”

A well-stocked buffet was furnished for the guests by the Suakin Mondirieh and Jack Jar did ample justice to the good things that were provided for him. I was glad to see Kaimakam Drury Bey, R.N., Controller of Sudan Ports, on his feet again and entertaining his sailor friends. He was greatly cheered and several Britishers carried him around the hall shoulder-high singing "He's a jolly good fellow.”

Among the guests were : Mr. Kerr, Acting Moudir of Suakin, Kaimakam Drury Bey, R.N., Controller Sudan Ports, Bimbashi Spencer, Inspector, Suakin Moudirieh, Bimbashi Ensor, Principle Medical Officer, Suakin Moudirieh, Commander Somerville, R.N., and all the officers of H.M.S. “Sealark,” Mr. Mackenzie, Superintendents Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited, Suakin, and several others.
H.M.S. “Sealark" went to sea again on the 26th for surveying purposes.
Miralai Macauley Bey, Director, Sudan Railways, went up as far as Railhead on the morning of the 23th inst. by a special train on inspection, returning to Suakin the same evening.

The Khedivial mail steamer “Mehallah” arrived here from Suet on the 28th inst, having on board Mr. C. M. Hickley, who has been acting Sudan Agent at Alexandria and who will now resume his duties with the Suakin-Atbara Bailway.

“The Magazine of Commerce.”—This excellent monthly publication is now in its third year of publication, and its success shows that it has met a great want on the part of the British manufacturer and merchant. As a medium for the dissemination of knowledge of centre British inventions to our colonial business houses, it should command an increased circulation—especially in these days of foreign enterprise. The standard of literary merit is a high one, the magazine is illustrated throughout, and in the number for December, 1904, will be found an interesting sketch of Lord Ribblesdale’s career, an excellent portrait of his lordship forming the frontispiece of this issue. The Magazine of Commerce is published at 155 and 156, Cheapside, London.

div.head: ACCESSION DAY.
RECEPTION AND REVIEW.
div.p: Yesterday’s Khedivial reception was largely attended, and from an early hour numbers visitors made their way to Abdeen Palace. The Diplomatic Agents and Consuls, the Minister and the Advisers, the heads of department, and many of the chief officers of the British Army of Occupation attended the reception, with a multitude of officials and notables. While it was in progess, many tourists and sight seers paid visits to Abdeen-square to watch the arrival of those who attended the reception, and to make guesses, sometimes very mistaken ones, at their identity.

Cairo was favored with bright, if cool, weather. The streets, in consequence of the general holiday, were crowded, and the square before the Khedivial Opera House, the neighbourhood of Abdeen, and the Esbekieh Gardens were gaily decorated.

The afternoon's review was a remarkably fine sight The appearance and marching of the troops was very good, and the cavalry, both when trotting and cantering past, went by splendidly, better even than last year. The galloping Maxims caused a good deal of interest to an enormous concourse.

The management of the crowd—there must have been more than 15,000 persons round the parade-ground—reflects great credit on the police, and that too though there was not room in the carriage enclosure for all the carriages whose occupants had tickets, and the standing room was decidedly limited. The police, however, did well—there was no unnecessary shooting, and the crowd, if packed pretty tightly, were as good-humoured as an Egyptian crowd can be.
The order of the review was as follows:—
Cavalry in line, artillery in line at half intervals.
lnfantry in quarter-column of half-battalions at Iff; paces interval.

After the infantry had passed and repassed the cavalry rode by at the trot and then at a canter. The Khedive took the salute from beside the standard. His Highness looked very well and was mounted on a very fine Arab. The principal officers of the staff and the bodyguard squadron were drawn up behind him. After the cavalry had cantered past, Lewa Lord Edward Cecil Pasha rode to the troops, followed by the officers of the Staff, and ordered the Khedivial salute, three times repeated by the troops and accompanied by the Khedivial Hymn. The Khedive then gave leave to dismiss the troops, and the review ended.

Cairo was brilliantly decorated last night, the streets were full, and the xxx proceeded merrily in the Esbekieh Gardens. The decorations were illuminated. A fine pillarlike erection had been got into place near the statue of Ibrahim Pasha and was decorated with red and green lamps and, on the summit, with the crescent and star in white lights. Musicians, conjurors, sweetmeat-sellers, etc., swarmed and by 9 p.m. it was quite clear that Cairo — native Cairo at least—was going to amuse itself till early morning.

div.head: MALTA.
div.p: The report of Governor Sir C. M. Clarke on the affairs of the Colony of Malta during 1903-4 has been published in the annual series of Colonial Reports (No. 439, Cd. 2238-16). The revenue for the year 1903-4, exclusive of the value of stores issued, was £464,391, and the expenditure £410,887. The excess of revenue over expenditure for the year was, therefore, £53,704. Including £142, the value of stores issued during the year, and £19,416, the surplus brought forward from 1902-3, the net surplus standing to the credit of the Government at the dose of the financial year was £73,262. The total value of dutiable goods imported in 1903-4 was £7,158,079, showing an increase of £595,281 over the value of the imports in the preceding year. The increase is almost entirely found under wheat, which shows an advance of £579,899. Of the total imports, £1,318,430 is the value of goods landed for local consumption, against £1,361,650 in 1902-3; and £5,839,649 is the value of dutiable goods re-exported in the same bottoms, as against £5,301,148 in the previous year. The value of the dutiable goods exported in 1903 4, exclusive of local produce,was £6,145,883, as against £5,849,576 in 1902-3. This represents an increase of £796,307. The value of whole cargoes which were carried in the same bottoms were £6,022,107, and that of the portions of cargoes which were landed and reexported was £123,776. The number of British ships which entered the ports of Malta in 1903-4 was 1,335, as against 1,837 in the previous year, and their tonnage was 2,464,464, as against 2,390,761—a decrease of two ships and an increase of 73,703 tons. Foreign steamships showed a total of 1,079, with a tonnage of 1,062,420, as against 1,030, with a tonnage of 1,069,299 in 1902-3, an increase of 49 in ships, with a decrease of 6,979. The principal event of 1903 was the visit of his Majesty King Edward VII., who arrived on April 16 on board the Royal yacht Victoria and Albert and remained in Malta till the morning of the 20th. This was the first occasion on which Malta had been honored by a visit from the reigning Sovereign, and the King received a loyal and enthusiastic welcome from all classes. The report contains much information as to finance, trade, agriculture, legislation, education, and other matters.

div.head: SIR W. WILLCOCKS’ JOURNEY.
div.p: From letters which have been received at Cairo it seems that Sir Wm. Willcocks was greatly struck by the possibilities of Koweit. He says it is capable of making a splendid harbour and should be the future Alexandria of that country. He is delighted with the climate, and the comparative nearness to the Himalayas make work there seem much more feasible. Of course. he is full of the grandeur of the Euphrates, and writing to a correspondent from Basra, Sir William says:— The Euphrates is a splendid river here, as wide as the Nile at Cairo and half as deep, with millions of date palms on every side. I hope the country will turn out propitious when I find myself at Bagdad, where I hope to be on the 23rd orv24th (December). I am in Sindbad the Sailor’s home. He would have made loss voyages if he had been cursed with quarantines in his day.

div.head: EGYPTOLOGICAL RESEARCH.
div.p: During the past year a strong local committee of Liverpool men in connection with the University of Liverpool has been formed to promote the study of archaeology, and has been strengthened by such well-known names in this connexion as those of Dr. Arthur Evans, Mr. Hilton Price, Prof. Ridgeway, and Prof. Boyd Dawkins. They have taken premises in Bedford-street, where they have established, in addition to a small but fairly complete library, a museum of Egyptian antiquities, presented for the most part by the local patrons of Egyptian exploration, such as Sir John Brunner, Mr. William Johnston, and Mr. John Rankin. Many of these were discovered by Mr. John Garstang, the newly appointed Lecturer in Archaeology, and there are to be found here the duplicate ivory tablet of Aha, found by him at Negadah last year, many of the other objects exhibited by him at the Society of Antiquaries in the summer, and an entirely representative collection from Beni Hassan and elsewhere. A reception held in this museum on Saturday week by Lady Alice Stanley fitly inaugurated the Institute, of which the Princess Henry of Battenberg is the patron ; and the course of lectures announced, which include the archaeology of Greece and Western Asia, as well as that of Egypt, leave nothing to be desired. The Institute has also arranged to conduct excavations on its own account at Edfu and Esneh during the forthcoming season.

div.head: THE UBIQUITOUS FIEND.
div.p: Some call it Influenza—
A simpler term is Grip—
The name were better Legion
(Of ills that it lets slip).
One says he has the toothache;
Another binds his ear;
A third cries ‘Little Mary's
Distinctly out of gear!'
‘A bronchial affection'
Makes this man croak and wheeze,
While that man’s quite exhausted
With trying not to sneeze.
'I wish you’d rub my shoulders !'
A dismal wight exclaims;
And 'How my head is splitting !’
Another lamb complains.
Alas! All red and swollen
Is someone’s pretty nose ;
And ‘Why is your eye bandaged!'
The same thing, I suppose!
'You want to go to dances;
You’ve got to stay in bed
And drink my nasty medicine,’
Was what the Doctor said.
‘Now light your little kettle,
And rub your little chest,
And gargle very often.
And try to sleep.’ (A jest)
Tve brought a little blister
That’s sure to do you good ;
It’s only Influenza.’
(With this they all conclude)
As though it did not matter,
As though it were a joke
Which you were bound to suffer
Along with other folk.
In London, New York, Cairo,
Wherever you may be
The Fiend is sure to grip you
In his ubiquitee.
P. M. C.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit--within certain necessary limits--free discussion.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN HOSPITAL
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—“Q.R.D.," in your issue of the 7th inst, has placed before your readers seriatim et numeratim the advantages afforded by this institution, with all of which I cordially concur. But I think that intending subscribers, before forwarding their donations, are entitled to be informed whether or not it is the fact that:—
(а) The hospital is used for maternity cases
(b) Soldiers' wives, or rather, the wives of soldiers belonging to the Army of Occupation, are received therein for their confinement gratuitously
(e) Fifteen out of the twenty-two beds, which is all the hospital contains, were occupied during the past year at one and the same period by cases of the above description

I think, moreover, it ought to be stated whether, assuming the above questions are answered in the affirmative, it was the intention of the founders of this hospital that it should be used for lying-in purposes and, furthermore, whether the executive committee intend to so use it henceforth.
I am, etc.,
Cairene.
Cairo, January 8.

div.head: CHARITY ORGANISATION SOCIETY.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Dear Sir,—Among the short paragraphs inserted above the initials “T. A.” under the heading “Under the Mosquito Net” in your issue of the 31st December last, the writer, in referring to “ cases of real destitution worthy o fhelp,” incidentally alludes in anything but complimentary terms to the Charity Organisation Society, which he (or she) most unfairly denominates that “Sham of Shams."

As an old subscriber to the abused society and a thorough believer, from knowledge, the good which for years past has resulted day by day from the fulfilment of the duties which the society in question has undertaken to perform, I cannot but think that “T. A" must have written his condemnation with but scant knowledge of facts, and perhaps will not object to my attempting to set him right and to my trying to prevent the injury which such comments might, if uncontradicted, inflict on a most deserving institution.

The Charity Organisation Society was not instituted for the administration of charitable funds, but for the guidance and assistance of the charitably disposed who might desire that their contributions to the aid of their less fortunate fellow-creatures should not pass into unworthy channels or assist in pauperising, instead of helping, those who might be willing although temporarily unable to support themselves and those dependent upon them.

From my own personal knowledge the secretary would be the last person to “turn a deaf oar” to any case of real distress which might come before him. It is not however part of the duty of this particular society to divert the proper employment of its funds to “seeking out" cases of distress, or to put itself into competition with other institutions, whether charitable or rate-aided, whose functions are different from its own, and which may be much better qualified to perform the work to which your correspondent refers.
Yours faithfully,
A. C. C.
Savoy Hotel, Assouan, 4th January, 1905.
